content: The Honoring America's Veterans and Caring for Camp Lejeune Families Act of 2012 (H.R. 1627, P.L. 112-154) is an omnibus bill impacting various veterans programs. It reflects a compromise agreement by House and Senate Committees on Veterans Affairs on multiple provisions from different bills. The Department of Veterans Affairs operates the nation's largest integrated health care system. The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) operates the nation's largest integrated health care system, providing medical care to veterans based on various eligibility factors. Special treatment authority for certain groups of veterans has been granted through legislation like the Veterans' Health Care, Training, and Small Business Loan Act of 1981 (P.L. 97-72). In 1981, Congress enacted the Veterans' Health Care, Training, and Small Business Loan Act of 1981 (P.L. 97-72), providing special authority for the VA to treat veterans for disorders possibly related to Agent Orange and ionizing radiation exposure. In 1993, P.L. 103-210 granted additional authority for the VA to provide health care for Persian Gulf War veterans with medical conditions possibly linked to toxic substances or environmental hazards during their service. In 1993, Congress passed P.L. 103-210 to authorize VA healthcare for Persian Gulf War veterans with conditions possibly related to toxic exposure. Section 706 of P.L. 112-154 sets time frames for initiating and completing debarment actions for veteran-owned small businesses that willfully misrepresented their status. It mandates that the VA start debarment proceedings within 30 days of such determination and complete them within 90 days. Debarment of a firm also includes debarment of all principals for a minimum of five years. The House and Senate Committees on Veterans' Affairs must report on VA-sponsored conferences with 50+ attendees costing $20,000+. Federal contractors with contracts over $100,000 must report employment data to the Department of Labor. P.L. 112-154 requires public disclosure of this information on a DOL website. The DOL Secretary is required to establish a website for public disclosure of information on veterans' employment by federal contractors. The VA Secretary is directed to establish the VetStar program to recognize businesses' contributions to veterans' employment annually.
